title: IOOF revealed as mystery bidder for HUB24
text:
IOOF has lobbed a $2.75 offer, but HUB24 shareholders aren't impressed. by Matthew Smith and Joyce Moullakis Financial services group IOOF Holdings has been revealed as the mystery bidder for HUB24 in an all cash non-binding and conditional proposal which valued the fast growing listed financial services technology company only slightly above its trading price.
Shares in HUB24 traded up 1.1per cent to $2.70 at the close of trade on Tuesday after the company revealed IOOF had made the $2.75 per share cash bid
The offer valued the company at $142 million.
But shareholders in the tightly held provider of technology and reporting solutions for independent financial advisers and self-directed investors were quick to point out the low premium the offer represented.
The IOOF offer was 3 per cent above where HUB24 shares were trading before it entered a trading halt on Tuesday morning, when news of the bid was revealed in Street Talk in The Australian Financial Review .
"We believe a price point above $3.10 is a more realistic offer price given the significant potential synergies. Further, there would also be some demand from other interested parties," said George Boubouras, Contago chief investment officer.
Another institutional investor who asked not to be named said the IOOF bid, "grossly underestimates the long-term value of the business".
It is understood there was an institutional bidder represented by a brokerage firm with a bid in the market for shares at $2.75 before the offer was revealed.
 Funds management firms Acorn Capital, Contango Asset Management and Thorney Holdings, along with company insiders, hold the bulk of the HUB24 shares.
HUB24 uses its own proprietary technology to provide portfolio management, transaction and reporting solutions for licensees, financial advisers, accountants, stockbrokers and institutions.
A potential acquisition of HUB24 is in line with the IOOF's moves to provide wealth management solutions for independent financial advisers and self-directed investors.
Early stage IOOF said in a statement its discussions with HUB24 remained at an "early stage" and highlighted its history for taking a disciplined approach to transactions.
In September 2013, IOOF walked away from competitive bidding process with rival investment firm, Perpetual, for The Trust Company.
In May last year the company paid $670 million to buy independent adviser group, Shadforth Financial Group, in a friendly takeover.
The Shadforth acquisition helped boost the company's underlying profits at its recent full-year earnings announcement by 43 per cent compared with the previous year.
HUB24 is one of the latest crop of listed financial services technology firms to target the self-directed and independent adviser market, alongside the likes of platform services company, Onevue Holdings, dealer group, Praemium and technology and information provider, Iress.
IOOF shares dropped 2.14 per cent to $8.68 at the end of trading on Tuesday following the announcement of its interest in HUB24. The broader market dropped 0.6 per cent.
